column4: Strictly speaking, learning the command line probably isn't required with Linux distros nowadays
but since most help is given as command line commands, it does help
the CLI is just the most convenient way of giving help.
without the use of cli -- most people are stuck :)
its the most powerful way of using the system.
I don't want to argue with you on this, but yes, it is. Anyone tells you otherwise, is kidding themselves.
I can't think of many scenarios where the command line would be strictly necessary.
Infinitely easier that the GUI way, yes, but not necessary.
like I said, I don't want to argue/discuss this with you -- just trust me when I tell you -- cli is necessary.
Heh. I can't accept such an argument .P

once you have administered remote computers, or had to troubleshoot or even USE a system over ssh, you will quickly learn to appreciate the cli. In fact, the GUI is entirely *optional* in linux, as witnessed by any server installation of ubuntu. Most people that know how to use linux will tell you, cli knowledge is essential, without it, you are just hoping nothing breaks, because then you are stuck.
then stop saying stuff like 'its not necessary'.
but for a common user, it's not necesary.
